conclusion: Liquid will flow out from A, B, C and D. Predict which container (E, F or G) it will flow into after passing through baffles.
There are four ramps: blue, grey, brown, and black.
The blue ramp is near the top and is oriented low-toward the right.
The grey ramp is in the center-right and is oriented low-toward the right.
The brown ramp is in the center-left and is oriented low-toward the right.
The black ramp is at the bottom-right and is oriented low-toward the left.

premise: Every stream is first bent rightward; if it is still high enough, it can be caught once more and bent further right, but the last ramp (black) sends what it touches back toward the middle and drops it more or less above the brown “house” reservoir.
conclusion: Streams are guided by ramps to flow in specific directions.
Stream A misses the blue ramp, lands on the long brown ramp, is carried far right, lands on the black ramp and is dumped just left of it.

premise: Stream A misses the blue ramp, lands on the long brown ramp, is carried far right, lands on the black ramp and is dumped just left of it.
conclusion: Stream A ends in reservoir F.
Stream B hits the upper part of the blue ramp, slides right, just reaches the grey ramp, slides right again and falls beyond the black ramp.

premise: Stream B hits the upper part of the blue ramp, slides right, just reaches the grey ramp, slides right again and falls beyond the black ramp.
conclusion: Stream B ends in reservoir G.
Stream C lands a little lower on the blue ramp than B; after the first rightward slide it misses the grey ramp, so it falls sooner and is caught by the black ramp, which tips it left.

premise: Stream C lands a little lower on the blue ramp than B; after the first rightward slide it misses the grey ramp, so it falls sooner and is caught by the black ramp, which tips it left.
conclusion: Stream C ends in reservoir F.
Stream D is already almost above the grey ramp, so it follows the same “double-right” course as B.

premise: Stream D is already almost above the grey ramp, so it follows the same “double-right” course as B.
conclusion: Stream D ends in reservoir G.
